title: Cape Krusenstern National Monument: Park Home
body: A Magical Landscape  North of the Arctic Circle, the monument forms 70 miles of shoreline on the Chukchi Sea.  More than 114 beach ridges provide evidence of human use for 5,000 years.  The Inupiat continue to use the area today.  Vast wetlands provide habitat for shorebirds from as far away as South America.  Hikers and boaters can see carpets of wildflowers among shrubs containing wisps of qiviut from muskoxen. Read More               A Window to the Past   For the past 5,000 years people have left evidence of their lives on the beach ridges of Cape Krusenstern.        World Class Birding   Over 150 species of birds migrate to Cape Krusenstern National Monument every summer to breed.              99 Ways to #FindYourPark   Celebrate 100 years of the National Park Service at Cape Krusenstern National Monument        Diary of a Subsistence User   Many Alaskans still live off the land, just like their ancestors have done for thousands of years.
